The ridiculous music ruins an otherwise interesting educational video. Noise. Perhaps it is the MUSIC tenderizing the cattle!

Ultrasonic cleaners rely on DIRECT contact with the part. The vacuum bag on the steak prevents this direct contact, therefore, the steak will not be heated nor cooked by ultrasonic. If you omit the vacuum bag, then the steak will be free floating in the cooking water, which is probably not the best way to prepare a steak.............

To all who "cook" sous vide ... please do some research into how you get malleable plastics... you are basically loading your food with the most toxic chemicals known to man + calling to cooking... I do believe that poisoning yourself = a more accurate description...

I think if you had a pot with Sous Vide heating up the water  and a pump to circulate the water with the Ultrasonic you can have the best of both worlds. This way you dial in your temperature and cooking time with Sous Vide and the Ultrasonic to help tenderize the meat.
I wonder if you could put a person in an ultrasonic cleaner, like those big ones you use for an engine or something

Just take a large capacity ultrasonic cleaner bring it up to temperature with the sous-vide unit circulator, then when it gets to temperature kick on the transducers without heat only the heat from the sous vide stick.
in between medium rare and medium is extra medium

FYI... It doesn't vibrate anything. The Sonic resonance causes cavitation within the liquid. Tiny "explosions", the cavitation of microscopic bubbles, literally "blows" dirt and grime off of the surface. This makes it ideal for getting into tiny crevasses and places you can't really reach.

Ultrasonic cleaners operate at 40khz which can cause cellular disruption which can tenderize the meat along with other uses like homogenizing & Cleaning. That's why you should never place your hand in a USC which can cause Bone Marrow & tissue Cellular degeneration.
Thats why you dont stick your fingers in the ultrasonic bath. The ultrasonic energy can cause cell damage.

In your experiment here would have liked to see a comparison between 40kHz and 23kHz ultrasonics.
The former is gentler (on articles to be cleaned) while the lower frequency creates larger cavitation 'bubbles' which are more powerful, but potentially more damaging to fine metal articles.


I wonder how meat would respond to the lower-frequency higher-power device?

Two considerations.
1: We know from a sous vide device that the temperature is measured accurately. How is that with an ultrasonic device? Maybe test it.
2: The soft plastic bag absorbs some of the ultrasonic waves. It is better to use a glass jar or eventually a hard plastic container.

Stirring the water is very important - temperature can vary by as much as 10 degrees C depending on where the heating element is and where temperature is measured. I discovered this from making my own sous vide cooker with a REX-C100 PID temperature controller and various water vessels - the best is using a rice cooker where stirring is unnecessary because the heating element is at the bottom covering the entire pot surface..

Generally, in an ultrasonic cleaner like that, the heating element is on the bottom side of the tray, and the steak was resting on it (so almost direct contact with the heat) which may explain why it cooked more compared to the sous vide (which as you pointed out, circulates the hot water around the pot an didn't have the steak in direct contact).
